segments.text: He says, how many damn machine guns do you have on those B-25s?
I said, well, some of them have five or six, and some of them have two or three.
He says, you literally plowed me a trench.
We just bombed and scraped the hell out of him.
But he escaped.
He said, I was ready to kill you guys.
Okay.
Well, I guess now could you kind of explain some, maybe the hardships that you endured that we hadn't already talked about, I guess.
We talked about the where-was.
Well, the worst hardship was no women.
See, for six months we had nothing to nurse or anything.
And I'm told there was a lot of homosexuals.
homosexual activity went up there.
Now, I heard that later, and I don't know how true it was.
I wasn't aware of it, but I wouldn't be surprised.
That was the worst hardship, was just no women, and food was marginal.
No whiskey, really, and no beer.
We got a shitload of beer in there, and I don't know, I think the Navy got most of it.
There just wasn't much to do, much in the way of recreation.
Of course, I had no drive.
I could have gone back to, in fact, some of the drive went back and it went up to Fairbanks.
Had my ball up there, but I don't know.
I don't know.
Can you kind of maybe go through a day, a normal day,
up there that, uh, just kind of go through the events that you would, you know, take place, I guess, from the time you got up to about the time you, from Reveille to Tafts, I guess.
Well, we wouldn't have any Reveille without a whistle.
No Reveille.
Uh...
Thank you for waiting.
Well, it's kind of hard to name a typical day because we would be assigned, we would be briefed and told where we were going when the fog lifted.
And then we would sit in this ready room, what they called the ready room, which originally was a tent.
And the well walked me the tent away and they brought in the
And we'd just sit there and play poker and bridge gambling.
And we'd go for walks, but we weren't allowed to go very far.
It had to be in whistling distance.
Then we'd go eat, which was more of a damn chore than a pleasure because there wasn't much to eat.
Red Stan.
Oh, I tell you, we used to have raids, excursions on the Navy.
The Navy had much better supplies than we did.
And so we'd go on raids and go and raid their vessel and get the food.
Get shot at, but nobody got hurt.
You know, we went raiding.
What did you do after that?
Just sat on and waited for those things.
Well, listen, we had one record player listen to those stupid records.
Judy Garland singing.
Put a little milk in her cow.
Oh, the Andrews sisters.
They got awful over it.
Why don't you do right?
Like some of the men did.
That was about it.
They ever...
I guess, send any movies or anything, any of the newsreels?
They had movies on Adak Island.
They had, and that's where I was first stationed.
I made my first raid out of Adak, and that was good living.
Adak was nice.
But on Amchitka, we didn't have anything in the way of entertainment.
What time do you normally go to bed in the evening, sir?
I guess the...
No.
We didn't, like I said, we didn't have any types of revelry.
We just had a whistle open.
We could sleep whenever we wanted to.
Unless we had some extra duty, like digging foxholes or something like that.
You know, officers were not supposed to work.
But we got hooked.
We had to dig our own foxhole.
No revelry, no revelry hours.
About how many men were stationed on Chitka?
Well, Chitka had a... Maybe they got a bunch of crews up there, heavy bombard B-24s, four-engine planes, but our B-25s created a normal complement of seven, six or seven men.
I don't know whether they're buried or what, but anyhow, the...
They had a total of, we had 20, 20 airplanes when we went up there.
We had about 10, I guess, when we came back.
20 times, what did I say?
20 times 7 is 140.
Okay.
All right.
In all, do you consider,
They got up on those boats and left, and we blamed the Navy for letting them get away.
Of course, you couldn't see your hands on your face, but we blamed the Navy.
The Navy blamed the Air Force because they didn't bomb them heavy enough.
Act II was a bloodbath.
Act II was a terrible bloodbath, and I didn't participate in it except for bombing.
But that was it.
Act II had Fish Hook Ridge.
And those poor old guys, they caught in hell.
They had frostbite.
The guys were pretty keen.
They weren't dumb.
I don't know how they happened to lose that war.
I guess they were just dumber than we were.
And we were pretty dumb.
But our troops went in.
The land hit.
And the command was to blame.
General Brown was commanding the troops, the ground troops.
And he took them in and dumped them in that cold water with no rubber boots.
So their feet got wet immediately.
And then the Japs let them come in.
They came in.
And came in, set up their tents, and they got all nice and situated.
Then the Japs hit them.
And they pinned them down.
in the valley.
They had a valley called Massacre Valley.
And it was surprising, because it was named for a battle that the Russians had had with the Lute Indians 100 years before.
And they had massacred the Lute Indians.
Well, they had a massacre that day.
They caught our boys, and they just pinned them down.
And they got frostbite, and they lost their toes.
And they went and cut a lot of their toes off.
We finally bombed them off from there, I think.
But they suffered a lot.
We never did.
I never suffered that much.
Thank God I wasn't an infantryman, I tell you.
Okay, well, is there any, I guess, anything you might want to add to all of this?
Well, there are a lot of anecdotes that I could add, but
They don't come to mind at the moment.
When I kind of made this word count, I told myself, I've got to chop this off.
It's going to be a book.
Now, I think a lot of things, you know, like the guy says, I think of a real clever answer to that after you go.
No, I think that's pretty well got it.
That damn chimp car that I preserved was a miserable mess.
As I said in here, I would have deserted, but there wasn't any place to go now.
